customer_name: Wildlife Images Rehabilitation and Education Center

citations.narrative:
The facility maintains computerized acquisition records for all four wolf hybrids instead of APHIS Form 7005 (Record of
Acquisition and Dogs and Cats on Hand) and APHIS Form 7006 (Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats) but does not
have an approved variance. Utilizing computerized records without a variance does not allow APHIS to review the
recordkeeping system prior to its approval to ensure it is comparable to required forms 7005 and 7006. The facility must
obtain and complete APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS Form 7006 for each wolf hybrid at the facility, or apply and be
approved for a variance from the requirement.
Correct by: October 18, 2024.

Along the base of both sides of the primary enclosure for the golden eagle, “Duchess”, are several sharp-edged segments
of rebar about 18 inches long located in level proximity to the eagle. Sharp edges and points affect animal welfare as this
may cause injury to the eagle especially if she is startled. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that
they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. Correct by eliminating sharp points or edges within the
golden eagle’s enclosure by 02-Oct-2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(2) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility maintains computerized acquisition records for all four wolf hybrids instead of APHIS Form 7005 (Record of 
Acquisition and Dogs and Cats on Hand) and APHIS Form 7006 (Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats) but does not 
have an approved variance. Utilizing computerized records without a variance does not allow APHIS to review the 
recordkeeping system prior to its approval to ensure it is comparable to required forms 7005 and 7006. The facility must 
obtain and complete APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS Form 7006 for each wolf hybrid at the facility, or apply and be 
approved for a variance from the requirement.  
Correct by: October 18, 2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Along the base of both sides of the primary enclosure for the golden eagle, “Duchess”, are several sharp-edged segments 
of rebar about 18 inches long located in level proximity to the eagle. Sharp edges and points affect animal welfare as this 
may cause injury to the eagle especially if she is startled. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that 
they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. Correct by eliminating sharp points or edges within the 
golden eagle’s enclosure by 02-Oct-2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n
